title: The science of snowflakes - Maruša Bradač

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the formation of a snowflake compared to an ice cube?

options.label: A
options.text: Snowflakes form when liquid water freezes into a solid, while ice cubes form when water vapor turns straight into ice.

options.label: B
options.text: Snowflakes form when water vapor turns straight into ice, while ice cubes form when liquid water freezes into a solid.

options.label: C
options.text: Snowflakes form when water vapor freezes into a solid, while ice cubes form when water vapor turns straight into ice.

options.label: D
options.text: Snowflakes and ice cubes form in the same way.

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason for the six-sided shape of a snowflake?

options.label: A
options.text: The six-sided shape is due to the angular shape of the water molecule.

options.label: B
options.text: The six-sided shape is due to the bonding between water molecules.

options.label: C
options.text: The six-sided shape is due to the hydrogen bonds between water molecules.

options.label: D
options.text: The six-sided shape is due to the atmospheric conditions in which the snowflake forms.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of warmer ground temperatures on snow?

options.label: A
options.text: It produces drier snow that is harder to pack.

options.label: B
options.text: It produces wetter snow that is easier to pack.

options.label: C
options.text: It produces snow that is neither wetter nor drier.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no effect on the type of snow.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to ski on completely dry snow?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the snowflakes are too small to provide sufficient friction.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the snowflakes are too jagged to provide sufficient friction.

options.label: C
options.text: Because there is too much friction between the jagged snowflakes and the ski surface.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the snowflakes are too heavy to provide sufficient friction.

multiple-choice.question: Why are snowflakes almost never identical?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the conditions at the six sharp edges of one snowflake are always different.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the conditions at the six sharp edges of one snowflake are similar, but the paths two snowflakes take are different.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the conditions at the six sharp edges of one snowflake are similar, and the snowflake's developing shape depends on atmospheric conditions.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the snowflakes are formed in different ways.

title: Why do we dream? - Amy Adkins

multiple-choice.question: According to Sigmund Freud, what is the primary function of dreams?

options.label: A
options.text: To help us remember important events from our past.

options.label: B
options.text: To fulfill our subconscious wishes and reveal our unconscious primitive thoughts, urges, and desires.

options.label: C
options.text: To rehearse our fight or flight instincts and keep them sharp.

options.label: D
options.text: To consolidate and create long-term memories.

options.label: A
options.text: Reverse learning theory

options.label: B
options.text: Continual activation theory

options.label: C
options.text: Primitive instinct rehearsal theory

options.label: D
options.text: Unconstrained problem-solving theory

multiple-choice.question: According to the continual activation theory, what is the primary function of dreams?

options.label: A
options.text: To help us remember important events from our past.

options.label: B
options.text: To keep our brains working by consolidating and creating long-term memories.

options.label: C
options.text: To rehearse our fight or flight instincts and keep them sharp.

options.label: D
options.text: To fulfill our subconscious wishes and reveal our unconscious primitive thoughts, urges, and desires.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the theory that suggests that dreams allow us to practice our fight or flight instincts and keep them sharp?

options.label: A
options.text: Reverse learning theory

options.label: B
options.text: Continual activation theory

options.label: C
options.text: Primitive instinct rehearsal theory

options.label: D
options.text: Unconstrained problem-solving theory

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one possible reason why people with certain mood disorders and PTSD often have difficulty sleeping?

options.label: A
options.text: Because their brains are not able to create long-term memories.

options.label: B
options.text: Because their brains are not able to consolidate and create long-term memories during REM sleep.

options.label: C
options.text: Because their brains are not able to take the edge off painful experiences during REM sleep.

options.label: D
options.text: Because their brains are not able to rehearse their fight or flight instincts during REM sleep.

title: Would you opt for a life with no pain? - Hayley Levitt and Bethany Rickwald

multiple-choice.question: According to Robert Nozick's thought experiment, the Experience Machine would provide a person with a life of only pleasure and never pain. However, this comes at the cost of permanently leaving reality behind. Would you sign up for this existence?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, I would sign up for the Experience Machine.

options.label: B
options.text: No, I would not sign up for the Experience Machine.

options.label: C
options.text: Maybe, it depends on the circumstances.

options.label: D
options.text: I'm not sure.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main purpose of Nozick's Experience Machine thought experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: To demonstrate the benefits of hedonism.

options.label: B
options.text: To refute the philosophical notion of hedonism.

options.label: C
options.text: To show that people would always choose the option that brings them the most pleasure.

options.label: D
options.text: To prove that people are always motivated by self-interest.

multiple-choice.question: In the thought experiment, Betsy is in a loving relationship with Xander, but unbeknownst to her, Xander has been having an affair with her sister, Angelica. According to hedonists, Betsy should remain in the dark about Xander's infidelity in order to maintain her high level of net pleasure. What would you do in Betsy's situation?

options.label: A
options.text: I would want to know the truth about Xander's infidelity.

options.label: B
options.text: I would not want to know the truth about Xander's infidelity.

options.label: C
options.text: I'm not sure, it depends on the circumstances.

options.label: D
options.text: I would ignore the situation and continue with my life.

multiple-choice.question: What is the value of real experiences, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Real experiences have no value beyond the pleasure they bring.

options.label: B
options.text: Real experiences have value beyond the pleasure they bring, such as truth, knowledge, and authentic connection with other human beings.

options.label: C
options.text: Real experiences are only valuable if they are pleasurable.

options.label: D
options.text: Real experiences are only valuable if they are painful.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main takeaway from Nozick's Experience Machine thought experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: That people are always motivated by self-interest.

options.label: B
options.text: That hedonism is the best philosophy for living a happy life.

options.label: C
options.text: That there is value in real experiences beyond the pleasure they bring.

options.label: D
options.text: That people should always choose the option that brings them the most pleasure.

options.label: A
options.text: If at least 8 of them guess correctly

options.label: B
options.text: If at least 9 of them guess correctly

options.label: C
options.text: If they all guess correctly

options.label: D
options.text: If they all guess incorrectly

multiple-choice.question: What is the strategy agreed upon by the humans to determine the color of their hats?

options.label: A
options.text: To count the total number of black hats and say "black" if it's odd and "white" if it's even

options.label: B
options.text: To agree on a specific word to use if they see an odd or even number of black hats

options.label: C
options.text: To try to look behind them and signal to the person behind them

options.label: D
options.text: To use a complex mathematical formula to determine the color of their hats

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to the strategy that allows the humans to guess their hat colors with absolute certainty?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to see the number of black hats in front of them

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to count the total number of black hats in the line

options.label: C
options.text: The use of parity information to determine the color of their hats

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to look behind them and see the color of the person behind them

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the first person in the line in the strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: To guess the color of their own hat and then look behind them to see the color of the person behind them

options.label: B
options.text: To convey parity information to the rest of the line by saying "black" or "white"

options.label: C
options.text: To count the total number of black hats in the line and then say "black" or "white" accordingly

options.label: D
options.text: To use a complex mathematical formula to determine the color of their hat

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome of the strategy if the ninth person in the line sees an odd number of black hats?

options.label: A
options.text: The first person in the line will guess incorrectly

options.label: B
options.text: The first person in the line will guess correctly

options.label: C
options.text: The first person in the line will be spared, but the rest of the humans will be eaten

options.label: D
options.text: The first person in the line will be eaten, but the rest of the humans will be spared

title: What "Orwellian" really means - Noah Tavlin

multiple-choice.question: What does the term "Orwellian" originally refer to?

options.label: A
options.text: The oppressive society depicted in George Orwell's novel "1984".

options.label: B
options.text: The totalitarian government in George Orwell's novel "1984".

options.label: C
options.text: The manipulative use of language by governments.

options.label: D
options.text: The critique of authoritarianism and totalitarianism by George Orwell.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the language created by the government in George Orwell's novel "1984" to control people's thoughts?

options.label: A
options.text: Newspeak

options.label: B
options.text: Doublethink

options.label: C
options.text: Ministry of Truth

options.label: D
options.text: Ministry of Love

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the hypnotic state of cognitive dissonance in which one is compelled to disregard their own perception in place of the officially dictated version of events?

options.label: A
options.text: Doublethink

options.label: B
options.text: Doubletalk

options.label: C
options.text: Doublespeak

options.label: D
options.text: Censorship

multiple-choice.question: According to George Orwell, what is the primary way in which language can shape our thoughts and opinions?

options.label: A
options.text: Through propaganda and historical facts

options.label: B
options.text: Through the use of pretentious words and euphemisms

options.label: C
options.text: Through the manipulation of our thoughts and perceptions

options.label: D
options.text: Through the elimination of words from the English language

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of George Orwell's essay that describes techniques used to manipulate language and affect our thoughts?

options.label: A
options.text: "Politics and the English Language"

options.label: B
options.text: "The Politics of Language"

options.label: C
options.text: "Language and Politics"

options.label: D
options.text: "The Power of Language"

title: Democracy - A short introduction

multiple-choice.question: What does the word "democracy" mean?

options.label: A
options.text: The rule of the king

options.label: B
options.text: The rule of the people

options.label: C
options.text: The rule of the government

options.label: D
options.text: The rule of the law

multiple-choice.question: Where did democracy first start as a direct democracy?

options.label: A
options.text: Ancient Rome

options.label: B
options.text: Ancient Greece, notably in the city-state of Athens

options.label: C
options.text: Ancient Egypt

options.label: D
options.text: Modern-day United States

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of a flawed democracy?

options.label: A
options.text: All people are treated equally and have the right to vote

options.label: B
options.text: Only certain groups of people are allowed to vote, such as men and landowners

options.label: C
options.text: The government makes all decisions without consulting the people

options.label: D
options.text: The people have complete control over the government

multiple-choice.question: What are the three branches of a modern democratic government?

options.label: A
options.text: The legislative, executive, and judicial

options.label: B
options.text: The executive, judicial, and military

options.label: C
options.text: The legislative, judicial, and economic

options.label: D
options.text: The executive, legislative, and social

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept developed by Jean-Jacques Rousseau that refers to the general will of a society?

options.label: A
options.text: The common good

options.label: B
options.text: The general will

options.label: C
options.text: The collective interest

options.label: D
options.text: The public interest

title: What makes the Great Wall of China so extraordinary - Megan Campisi and Pen-Pen Chen

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary purpose of the Great Wall of China when it was first built?

options.label: A
options.text: To protect China from Mongol, Turkish, and Xiongnu invasions.

options.label: B
options.text: To connect the Tibetan Plateau and Pacific Ocean.

options.label: C
options.text: To showcase China's architectural skills.

options.label: D
options.text: To create a barrier between China and other countries.

multiple-choice.question: Who expanded the small walls built by his predecessors and connected some and fortified others to defend against Mongol, Turkish, and Xiongnu invasions?

options.label: A
options.text: Emperor Qin Shi Huang

options.label: B
options.text: Emperor Han-Wudi

options.label: C
options.text: Genghis Khan

options.label: D
options.text: Khublai Khan

multiple-choice.question: What was the average height and width of the Great Wall during the Ming dynasty?

options.label: A
options.text: 10 feet high and 5 feet wide

options.label: B
options.text: 15 feet high and 10 feet wide

options.label: C
options.text: 23 feet high and 21 feet wide

options.label: D
options.text: 30 feet high and 25 feet wide

multiple-choice.question: Why did the Great Wall lose its purpose after the Qing dynasty came to power in 1644?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the wall was damaged during the Mongol invasion.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the empire's borders now extended beyond the Great Wall.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the wall was not well-maintained.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the wall was not effective in keeping out invaders.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of the Great Wall of China today?

options.label: A
options.text: To serve as a military defense system.

options.label: B
options.text: To showcase China's architectural skills.

options.label: C
options.text: To attract tourists and generate revenue.

options.label: D
options.text: To serve as a cultural and historical landmark.

title: When to use "me", "myself" and "I" - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between the subject and object pronouns in a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: The subject pronoun is the one that performs the action, while the object pronoun is the one that receives the action.

options.label: B
options.text: The subject pronoun is the one that receives the action, while the object pronoun is the one that performs the action.

options.label: C
options.text: The subject pronoun is the one that is acted upon, while the object pronoun is the one that acts.

options.label: D
options.text: The subject pronoun is the one that is the object of a preposition, while the object pronoun is the one that is the subject.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following sentences is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: "Me heard gossip."

options.label: B
options.text: "I heard gossip."

options.label: C
options.text: "Me and I heard gossip."

options.label: D
options.text: "Myself heard gossip."

multiple-choice.question: When should you use the reflexive pronoun "myself" in a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: When it's the subject of the sentence.

options.label: B
options.text: When it's the object of a sentence whose subject is "I."

options.label: C
options.text: When it's the object of a sentence whose subject is "me."

options.label: D
options.text: When it's the subject of a sentence whose subject is "myself."

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the intensive pronoun "myself" in a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: To add emphasis to the subject of the sentence.

options.label: B
options.text: To add emphasis to the object of the sentence.

options.label: C
options.text: To intensify the action of the sentence.

options.label: D
options.text: To add a new subject to the sentence.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following sentences is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: "Please tell Jack or myself."

options.label: B
options.text: "Please tell Jack or I."

options.label: C
options.text: "Please tell Jack or me."

options.label: D
options.text: "Please tell Jack and myself."

options.label: B
options.text: Grammar

options.label: C
options.text: Productivity

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Charlie

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

options.label: A
options.text: Human language is more complex

options.label: B
options.text: Human language has more productive and grammatical rules

options.label: C
options.text: Human language can communicate about imaginary things

options.label: D
options.text: Human language is only used for speaking

title: Can you solve the bridge riddle? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: How long does it take for the zombies to catch up to the group?

options.label: A
options.text: 15 minutes

options.label: B
options.text: 17 minutes

options.label: C
options.text: 20 minutes

options.label: D
options.text: 25 minutes

options.label: A
options.text: The lab assistant

options.label: B
options.text: The janitor

options.label: C
options.text: The professor

options.label: D
options.text: The narrator

Why is it necessary for anyone crossing the bridge to either hold the lantern or stay right next to it?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's too dark to see otherwise

options.label: B
options.text: Because the lantern is the only source of light

options.label: C
options.text: Because anyone crossing must be able to see the bridge

options.text: Because the lantern is the only way to navigate the bridge

multiple-choice.question: Why is it beneficial to have the fastest people available to make return trips with the lantern?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they can carry the lantern more easily

options.label: C
options.text: Because they can minimize the time wasted by the two slowest people

options.label: D

title: How smart are dolphins? - Lori Marino

multiple-choice.question: What is one way dolphins demonstrate their intelligence and ability to communicate?

options.label: A
options.text: They can recognize and mimic the voices of different languages.

options.label: B
options.text: They can pass down their communication methods and other skills from generation to generation.

options.label: C
options.text: They can only communicate through body language.

options.label: D
options.text: They can only communicate through clicks and whistles.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the group of dolphins that has learned how to cover their rostrums with sponges when rooting in sharp corals?

options.label: A
options.text: The Dolphin Sponge Club

options.label: B
options.text: The Coral Dolphin Squad

options.label: C
options.text: The Australian Dolphin Gang

options.label: D
options.text: The Sponge Dolphins

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the test that dolphins are able to pass, indicating physical self-awareness and metacognition?

options.label: A
options.text: The Mirror Test

options.label: B
options.text: The Empathy Test

options.label: C
options.text: The Altruism Test

options.label: D
options.text: The Attachment Test

multiple-choice.question: What is one example of dolphins demonstrating their ability to process complex information and understand language?

options.label: A
options.text: They can learn to count up to 10.

options.label: B
options.text: They can understand the difference between bringing the ball to the hoop and bringing the hoop to the ball.

options.label: C
options.text: They can recognize and mimic the sounds of different animals.

options.label: D
options.text: They can only understand simple commands.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way dolphins demonstrate their sense of empathy and altruism?

options.label: A
options.text: They can recognize and help injured individuals of other species.

options.label: B
options.text: They can only help injured individuals of their own species.

options.label: C
options.text: They can only communicate through body language.

options.label: D
options.text: They can only help injured individuals in their own group.

title: How false news can spread - Noah Tavlin

multiple-choice.question: What phenomenon occurs when publication A publishes misinformation, publication B reprints it, and publication A then cites B as the source for the information?

options.label: A
options.text: Confirmation bias

options.label: B
options.text: Circular reporting

options.label: C
options.text: Confirmation of facts

options.label: D
options.text: Verification of sources

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of circular reporting where a satirical article was referenced in serious science publications over 400 times?

options.label: A
options.text: A joke article in the British Medical Journal about energy expenditure in adolescents playing computer games

options.label: B
options.text: A serious article in the British Medical Journal about the effects of vaccination on children

options.label: C
options.text: A satirical article in a popular magazine about the benefits of a new diet

options.label: D
options.text: A serious article in a reputable science publication about the effects of climate change

multiple-choice.question: What is a common contributor to circular reporting?

options.label: A
options.text: User-generated content, such as social media posts

options.label: B
options.text: User-generated content, such as wikis

options.label: C
options.text: Mainstream media outlets

options.label: D
options.text: Academic journals

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the phenomenon where a lie can travel quickly around the world while the truth is still verifying its facts?

options.label: A
options.text: Confirmation bias

options.label: B
options.text: Circular reporting

options.label: C
options.text: The speed of information

options.label: D
options.text: A lie can travel halfway around the world while the truth is putting on its shoes

multiple-choice.question: What can help slow down a lie and give the truth more time to be verified?

options.label: A
options.text: Avoiding sensationalist media and searching for criticisms of suspicious information

options.label: B
options.text: Tracing the original source of a report and verifying its facts

options.label: C
options.text: Sharing the information on social media

options.label: D
options.text: Ignoring the information altogether
